Then Job answered and said,
I know <FI>it is<Fi> so of a truth: but how should man be just with God?<RF>with God: or, before God?<Rf>
If he will contend with him, he cannot answer him one of a thousand.
<FI>He is<Fi> wise in heart, and mighty in strength: who hath hardened <FI>himself<Fi> against him, and hath prospered?
Which removeth the mountains, and they know not: which overturneth them in his anger.
Which shaketh the earth out of her place, and the pillars thereof tremble.
Which commandeth the sun, and it riseth not; and sealeth up the stars.
Which alone spreadeth out the heavens, and treadeth upon the waves of the sea.<RF>waves: Heb. heights<Rf>
Which maketh Arcturus, Orion, and Pleiades, and the chambers of the south.<RF>Arcturus…: Heb. Ash, Cesil, and Cimah<Rf>
Which doeth great things past finding out; yea, and wonders without number.
Lo, he goeth by me, and I see <FI>him<Fi> not: he passeth on also, but I perceive him not.
Behold, he taketh away, who can hinder him? who will say unto him, What doest thou?<RF>hinder…: Heb. turn him away?<Rf>
<FI>If<Fi> God will not withdraw his anger, the proud helpers do stoop under him.<RF>proud…: Heb. helpers of pride, or, strength<Rf><CM>
How much less shall I answer him, <FI>and<Fi> choose out my words <FI>to reason<Fi> with him?
Whom, though I were righteous, <FI>yet<Fi> would I not answer, <FI>but<Fi> I would make supplication to my judge.
If I had called, and he had answered me; <FI>yet<Fi> would I not believe that he had hearkened unto my voice.
For he breaketh me with a tempest, and multiplieth my wounds without cause.
He will not suffer me to take my breath, but filleth me with bitterness.
If <FI>I speak<Fi> of strength, lo, <FI>he is<Fi> strong: and if of judgment, who shall set me a time <FI>to plead<Fi>?
If I justify myself, mine own mouth shall condemn me: <FI>if I say<Fi>, I <FI>am<Fi> perfect, it shall also prove me perverse.
<FI>Though<Fi> I <FI>were<Fi> perfect, <FI>yet<Fi> would I not know my soul: I would despise my life.<CM>
This <FI>is<Fi> one <FI>thing<Fi>, therefore I said <FI>it<Fi>, He destroyeth the perfect and the wicked.
If the scourge slay suddenly, he will laugh at the trial of the innocent.
The earth is given into the hand of the wicked: he covereth the faces of the judges thereof; if not, where, <FI>and<Fi> who <FI>is<Fi> he?<CM>
Now my days are swifter than a post: they flee away, they see no good.
They are passed away as the swift ships: as the eagle <FI>that<Fi> hasteth to the prey.<RF>swift…: or, ships of Ebeh: Heb. ships of desire<Rf>
If I say, I will forget my complaint, I will leave off my heaviness, and comfort <FI>myself<Fi>:
I am afraid of all my sorrows, I know that thou wilt not hold me innocent.
<FI>If<Fi> I be wicked, why then labour I in vain?
If I wash myself with snow water, and make my hands never so clean;
Yet shalt thou plunge me in the ditch, and mine own clothes shall abhor me.<RF>abhor…: or, make me to be abhorred<Rf>
For <FI>he is<Fi> not a man, as I <FI>am, that<Fi> I should answer him, <FI>and<Fi> we should come together in judgment.
Neither is there any daysman betwixt us, <FI>that<Fi> might lay his hand upon us both.<RF>any…: Heb. one that should argue<Rf><RF>daysman: or, umpire<Rf>
Let him take his rod away from me, and let not his fear terrify me:
<FI>Then<Fi> would I speak, and not fear him; but <FI>it is<Fi> not so with me.<RF>it is…: Heb. I am not so with myself<Rf><CM>
